pages.content:
SIDDARAMAIAH PRESENTS
A GROWTH-ORIENTED BUDGET FOR ALL
· Fakir Balaji
ฮลวยพร สออยซ์
Đ: 02-08-90.990
Karnataka Chief Minister
Mr. Siddaramaiah presented a
growth-oriented Budget for fiscal
2025-26 in the state assembly on
March 7, 2025, with allocations for
all sections, including beneficiaries
of his government's flagship 5
Guarantees.
Reading the Budget proposals in
Kannada, the Chief Minister, who
also holds the Finance portfolio,
told the lawmakers that as in the
past, his record 16th budget was
meant to uplift the poor, women,
farmers, youth and weaker sections
across the state.
"I have implemented many welfare
programmes for the upliftment
of the poor, women, the exploited
and weaker sections. I have also
provided funds for capital projects
to boost the state's economic
growth. My 16th Budget is also
formulated with this objective in
mind," Mr. Siddaramaiah told the
media later.
Asserting that the State Government
had the responsibility of ensuring
resources to everyone, the Chief
Minister said by balancing economic
development with people's welfare,
the State's development model was
shaped through Universal Basic
Income.
4
March of Karnataka April 2025

Mr. Siddaramaiah presented a

Reading the Budget proposals in

told the lawmakers that as in the
past, his record 16th budget was
meant to uplift the poor, women,
farmers, youth and weaker sections

"I have implemented many welfare

pages.content:
"Many of our welfare programmes, including the
Guarantees are not freebies but strategic investments
based on economic and social principles. They are answers
to many socio-economic questions raised at international
fora. Our schemes are for increasing people's purchasing
power. While empowering women, we are making efforts
to address the environmental crisis through the green
economy," Mr. Siddaramaiah said.
The budget focuses on implementing the programmes for
the prosperity of various groups, including the Scheduled
Castes (SCs), Scheduled Tribes (STs), Backward Classes
(BCs), minorities, women, farmers and labourers.
Holistic Growth
As agriculture, horticulture, sericulture, animal husbandry,
fisheries and rural development are complementary sectors,
the State Government will launch schemes to increase
income and drive growth across the southern state. Efforts
will be made to develop villages by registering agricultural
and other assets, providing infrastructure, power supply
and warehouses.
As the infrastructure sector drives the state's holistic
growth, funds are allotted for capital expenditure, which is
47.3 per cent more than allocated in the budget for fiscal
2024-25. Investments in health and education will build a
healthy society. Emphasis will be on urban development
projects to provide infrastructure and quality services to
citizens across the state.
As the largest revenue contributor to the state exchequer,
Bangalore has ambitious projects under "Brand Bengaluru"
to improve its infrastructure, service delivery and traffic
flow. Efforts are on to reduce pressure on the Metropolis by
developing tier-2 and tier-3 cities
in the surrounding areas of the
garden city.
New
policies
are
being
implemented in the Micro, Small,
Medium Enterprises (MSMEs),
tourism and IT-BT sectors to
create jobs. Priority is given to
create a favourable environment
for attracting investments and
more employment across the
state.
"To enhance transparency and
efficiency in governance and
curb corruption, technology is being leveraged effectively.
We will implement strategies to provide people-friendly
and efficient services by adopting administrative reforms,
simplifying service delivery and enforcing transfer policies
through counselling. Measures like direct cash transfers
exemplify our government's accountability," the Chief
"I am presenting a budget, focusing on
sustainable economic growth while ensuring
fiscal consolidation. By prioritizing key sectors
such as infrastructure, irrigation and social
welfare, we are laying the foundation for long-
term prosperity. At the same time, the fiscal
discipline we have outlined will ensure stability
and strengthen the financial position of the
State. As we move forward, this budget will not
only foster growth, but also secure a strong fiscal
health of the state," Mr Siddaramaiah added.
Empowering
Farmers with
Innovation
₹ 5,000 small processing units
to be established across
Karnataka
12,000 farm ponds under
Krishi Bhagya scheme
₹ Digital Agri Service Centres to
aid precise decision-making
for crops
FKARNATAKA
BUDGET 2025-26
A Budget that Guarantees Progress
DEPARTMENT OF INFORMATION AND PUBLIC RELATION
#NammaBudget2025 #KarnatakaBudget2025
Minister reiterated.
Mr. Siddaramaiah also assured legislators that the State
Government
would
eliminate regional disparities,
strengthen education and health sectors, ensure efficient
transport and maintain law and order.
New Industrial Policy
As one of the fastest-growing states, contributing 8.4 per cent
to the National Gross Domestic
Product
(GDP),
Karnataka
continued its impressive growth
trajectory in fiscal 2024-25 and
is poised to achieve a Gross
State Domestic Product (GSDP)
growth rate of 7.4 per cent,
outpacing the national growth
rate of 6.4 per cent in 2024-25.
Agriculture sector registered a
4 per cent growth rate as against
negative (-) 4.9 per cent in the last
fiscal 2023-24 due to drought and
a weak monsoon. The positive
growth rate in 2024-25 is owing to proactive interventions
to encourage kharif sowing, aided by a normal monsoon
and adequate reservoir levels. Rs 51,339 crore is allocated
for the farming sector in the new fiscal as against Rs 44,000
crore in 2024-25.
Known for its investor-friendly ecosystem, Karnataka

pages.content:
Signal-free Roads
"The State Government has stood guarantee to the
BBMP for Rs. 19,000 crore to undertake the North-
South and the East-West corridors (tunnels) at a cost
of Rs. 40,000 crore. To mitigate vehicular congestion
and ensure smooth traffic, major roads across the city
will be made signal-free," Mr. Siddaramaiah said.
A 40.5km double decker flyover will be built at a cost
of Rs. 8,916 crore along with Namma Metro phase-3
project; a network of 300km additional roads will be
constructed at a cost of Rs.3,000 crore, utilising canal
buffer zones; arterial and sub-arterial road network
measuring 460km will be developed at a cost of
Rs.660 crore; flyovers and grade separators of 120km
length will be built across the city.
To strengthen the 'Brand Bengaluru' plan, Rs. 1,800
crore was earmarked for 21 schemes during fiscal
2024-25. Over the next 3 years, a 'comprehensive
health programme' will be initiated at a cost of Rs.413
crore to make Bengaluru a city of global health
standards.
"The State Government will provide BBMP and
BWSSB Rs. 3,000 crore to build a drainage network
and sewage treatment plants (STPs) to control
climate change induced flooding in Bengaluru," Mr.
Siddaramaiah said.
is committed to job-centric and inclusive development
of the manufacturing sector across the state. With a new
Industrial Policy for 2025-30, the State Government is
aiming to achieve 12 per cent growth and 20-lakh jobs by
2030. Industrial sector achieved 5.8 per cent growth in 2024-
25. To attract huge investments, the State Government has
committed to give financial assistance and subsidies worth
Rs 13,692 crore to investors.
With the service sector contributing a whopping 66 per
cent to the state economy in gross value addition (GVA),
it registered an 8.9 per cent growth rate in 2024-25. The
State Government has implemented several policies in the
services sectors, including IT, Tourism and Biotechnology
to spur economic growth and create more jobs. These
policies will promote investments in diverse sectors with
optimal use of its human resources.
"Our policies are expected to attract about Rs 1-lakh
crore investment in the state. To facilitate investments in
these sectors, the State Government has offered subsidies
and financial aid to the tune of Rs 13,500 crore. Focus
on economic growth has drawn $4.4 billion foreign
investments up to December 2024, ranking the state third
in the country," Mr. Siddaramaiah noted.
Though Karnataka is known for prudent fiscal policy, debt
management and adherence to fiscal discipline, the Central
Government's unwillingness to compensate for GST
revenue loss of Rs 2,53,287 crore, non-devolution of cess and
surcharges and lower tax devolution from the 15th Finance
Commission have compounded its fiscal challenges. As
a result, the state has been facing headwinds in pursuing
long-term growth with social justice. Undeterred by the
Centre's step-motherly treatment, the state has managed its
expenditure commitments by mobilising resources.
Decisive Step
Total budget for fiscal 2025-26 is estimated at Rs 4,09,549
crore, which is a new milestone, and has increased from Rs
2,65,720 crore in 2022-23 Budget Estimates (BE), registering
54 per cent growth under the Fiscal Responsibility and
Budget Management (FRBM) Act.
"When our government came to power, the opposition
criticised the 5 Guarantee Schemes and doubted their
success. However, we have implemented them by allocating
funds. For the ensuing fiscal (2025-26), Rs. 51,034 crore has
been allocated for all the five schemes," the Chief Minister
affirmed.
Noting that the budget for the new fiscal (2025-26)
would be remembered for giving a big push to the capital
expenditure and setting a new charter for economic growth,
Mr. Siddaramaiah said the state's gross capital expenditure
increased to Rs 83,200 crore in 2025-26 (BE) from Rs
56,492 crore in 2024-25 (BE), which is an increase of 47.3
per cent on annual basis.
"It is a remarkable jump as it will create a virtuous cycle of
investment and economic growth. It accounts for 2.32 per
cent of the state's GSDP, up from 1.99 per cent in 2024-25.
We have taken a decisive step towards making Karnataka
the country's number one economy. Priority is given to
irrigation, road building, infrastructure and comprehensive
development of Bengaluru," Mr. Siddaramaiah said in his
marathon budget speech.
To meet the infrastructure needs of Bengaluru, the State
Government is taking up multiple projects, including
120km flyovers and grade separators, 320km of new roads
along buffer zones of canals, arterial and sub-arterial roads
and a double-decker flyover, with a cumulative investment
of Rs. 54,000 crore over the next 3 years. In addition, a new
Peripheral Ring Road (PRR) at a cost of Rs 27,000 crore and
an underground tunnel at a cost of Rs 40,000 crore are in
the pipeline.
"We have increased budgetary allocation for Bengaluru
infrastructure to Rs 7,000 crore in 2025-26 from Rs 3,000
crore in 2024-25," the Chief Minister announced.
March of Karnataka April 2025
6

pages.content:
Kalyana Karnataka
To promote innovation and entrepreneurship in other
cities besides Bengaluru, a new scheme -- Local Economic
Accelerator Programme (LEAP) will be launched at a cost
of Rs 1,000 crore, with Rs 200 crore allocation for 2025-26.
In addition to funds for the 5 Guarantee Schemes,
honorarium for ASHA workers, Anganwadi workers, mid-
day meal workers, guest teachers, Pre-University lecturers
as well as monthly allowances for journalists, artists and
wrestlers have been increased. The budget also proposes an
increase in the honorarium for Hindu, Jain and Sikh priests
and Pesh Imams and Muezzins.
Under Kalyana Karnataka Regional Development Board,
works will be taken up at an estimated cost of Rs 5,000
crore during 2025-26. Total allocation under SCSP/TSP is
Rs.42,018 crore as against Rs 39,121 crore in 2024-25, which
is an increase of Rs 2,897 crore. Gender Budget has been
increased to Rs 94,084 crores in 2025-26 from Rs 86,372
crore in 2024-25, an increase of Rs 7,711 crore.
Recognising the importance of children in building a
stronger economy and society in the near future, the
allocation for child budget has been increased to Rs 62,033
crore in 2025-26 from Rs 55,933 crores in 2024-25, an
increase of Rs 6,100 crore.
A new scheme called the Chief Minister's Infrastructure
Development Programme (CMIDP) is being launched
with Rs. 8,000 crore to ensure balanced development across
the state, focusing on minor irrigation, roads and urban
infrastructure in all the assembly constituencies of the state.
"Our government has implemented Raita Samruddi Yojane
to make the agriculture sector profitable and sustainable for
small and marginal farmers. Plots of an integrated farming
system as a model will be developed in each of the 10 agro-
climatic zones for demonstration to farmers for adoption
under the scheme. Assistance of Rs.428 crore will be
provided to 50,000 farmers across the state under the Farm
Mechanisation Scheme. To increase agriculture production
in rain-fed areas by efficient utilisation of water, Rs 440
crore will be provided to 1.81-lakh farmers for adoption of
micro irrigation," the Chief Minister said.
Agricultural Loans
A Knowledge Cell will be set up by the Indian Institute
of Space Science and Technology in partnership with
private players to provide farmers with real-time data on
the extent, production, crop health and market data about
horticultural crops by using satellite and other modern
technologies. A seed bank will be established to conserve
the 20 GI tagged and other indigenous crops which are on
the verge of extinction.

for Fisherfolk
₹
₹30 Cr for development of
fisheries-linked roads in
coastal districts
₹ Up to 21 Lakh subsidy for
replacing engines older than
15 years in mechanised
boats

lines.text: Kalyana Karnataka
To promote innovation and entrepreneurship in other
cities besides Bengaluru, a new scheme -- Local Economic
Accelerator Programme (LEAP) will be launched at a cost
of Rs 1,000 crore, with Rs 200 crore allocation for 2025-26.
In addition to funds for the 5 Guarantee Schemes,
honorarium for ASHA workers, Anganwadi workers, mid-
day meal workers, guest teachers, Pre-University lecturers
as well as monthly allowances for journalists, artists and
wrestlers have been increased. The budget also proposes an
increase in the honorarium for Hindu, Jain and Sikh priests
and Pesh Imams and Muezzins.
Under Kalyana Karnataka Regional Development Board,
works will be taken up at an estimated cost of Rs 5,000
crore during 2025-26. Total allocation under SCSP/TSP is
Rs.42,018 crore as against Rs 39,121 crore in 2024-25, which
is an increase of Rs 2,897 crore. Gender Budget has been
increased to Rs 94,084 crores in 2025-26 from Rs 86,372
crore in 2024-25, an increase of Rs 7,711 crore.
Recognising the importance of children in building a
stronger economy and society in the near future, the
allocation for child budget has been increased to Rs 62,033
crore in 2025-26 from Rs 55,933 crores in 2024-25, an
increase of Rs 6,100 crore.
A new scheme called the Chief Minister's Infrastructure
Development Programme (CMIDP) is being launched
with Rs. 8,000 crore to ensure balanced development across
the state, focusing on minor irrigation, roads and urban
infrastructure in all the assembly constituencies of the state.
"Our government has implemented Raita Samruddi Yojane
to make the agriculture sector profitable and sustainable for
small and marginal farmers. Plots of an integrated farming
system as a model will be developed in each of the 10 agro-
climatic zones for demonstration to farmers for adoption
under the scheme. Assistance of Rs.428 crore will be
provided to 50,000 farmers across the state under the Farm
Mechanisation Scheme. To increase agriculture production
in rain-fed areas by efficient utilisation of water, Rs 440
crore will be provided to 1.81-lakh farmers for adoption of
micro irrigation," the Chief Minister said.
Agricultural Loans
A Knowledge Cell will be set up by the Indian Institute
of Space Science and Technology in partnership with
private players to provide farmers with real-time data on
the extent, production, crop health and market data about
horticultural crops by using satellite and other modern
technologies. A seed bank will be established to conserve
the 20 GI tagged and other indigenous crops which are on
the verge of extinction.

#NammaBudget2025 #KarnatakaBudget2025
has reduced the limit of refinancing at subsidised interest
rate by 58 per cent, the State Government is committed to
achieve the target. It is aimed to disburse loans worth Rs.
28,000 crore to 37-lakh farmers in the year ending March
31, 2025. Interest waiver scheme on medium and long-term
loans of DCC and PCARD banks was announced in the
Belagavi session of 2023-24. Under this scheme, Rs.240
crore interest on the loans has been waived off.
Urdu Medium Schools
The State Government will provide an additional Rs. 450
over and above Rs. 7,550 per quintal under the Minimum
Support Price (MSP) scheme for procurement of tur dal
with a total expenditure of Rs. 138 crore to benefit farmers of
Kalaburagi, Bidar, Yadagiri, Vijayapura, Bagalkot, Raichur,
Koppal, Kolar, Chitradurga and Chikkaballapur districts.
Under the 'Akshara Aavishkara' scheme, 50 schools in
Kalyana Karnataka region will be upgraded as Karnataka
Public Schools at a cost of Rs. 200 crore. A total of 5,267
vacant teaching posts in Government Primary and High
Schools in Kalyana Karnataka region will be filled. Action
will be taken to rationalise the remaining vacancies and
steps will be taken to fill 5,000 posts.
Bangalore City University will be renamed as Dr. Manmohan
Singh Bengaluru City University. To make this a model
university in the country, Government Arts College and
Government R.C. College will be made constituent colleges
Business Corridor
Cauvery stage-v project with an additional water
capacity of 775 million litres per day (MLD) was
implemented at a cost of Rs. 5,550 crore and
dedicated in 2024-25 to provide drinking water to
50-lakh residents in 110 villages around the city.
With the objective of generating biogas-based
income and carbon credits by using waste generated
in STP units, BWSSB will formulate a programme
in PPP (Public-Private Partnership) model.
A Rs. 27,000-crore plan has been prepared to build
a 73km road with assistance from HUDCO Bank
by renaming the long-pending Peripheral Ring
Road project as 'Bengaluru Business Corridor'.
Land acquisition process has begun by separate
teams.
As Namma Metro plays a vital role in easing the
vehicular congestion across the city by providing
mobility service to 8.5-lakh commuters daily on
its 79.65km rail network, spanning 68 stations, it
is envisaged to add 98.60km routes in the next two
years.
Under 'Brand Bengaluru-Green Bengaluru', works
related to 14 lakes are under progress through
BBMP at a cost of Rs. 35 crore. Varthur lake and
Bellandur lake rejuvenation works have been taken
up at a cost of Rs. 234 crore by the Bengaluru
Development Authority (BDA).
Similarly, 70km of railway lines will be doubled on
the Baiyappanahalli-Hosur and Yeshwantapura-
Channasandra routes at a cost of Rs.812 crore. The
State Government is providing Rs.406 crore for
the doubling projects. The Bengaluru Suburban
Railway Project is being implemented at a cost of
Rs.15,767 crore. The project consists of a 148km
length of rail network and 58 stations. Works for
two corridors of the total four corridors are in
progress. Tender process for other two corridors
will be completed to implement the project in a
time-bound manner.
"A hi-tech Bengaluru Signature Park will be
developed at Devanahalli in 407 acres of land.
Rs.50 crore has been released under the State
Government funds to provide connectivity to
the Park with a flyover. Majestic bus stand in the
city centre will be re-developed under the PPP
model. A transport hub consisting of a commercial
complex will be built," Mr. Siddaramaiah added./

A Budget that Guarantees Progress
#NammaBudget2025 #KarnatakaBudget2025
The Karnataka Budget has more than
doubled the yearly grant for ramping up
infrastructure works in Bengaluru to Rs
7,000 crore for fiscal 2025-26 from Rs 3,000
crore in 2024-25. As the hi-tech city makes
a major contribution to the state economy,
Chief Minister Siddaramaiah said a Special
Purpose Vehicle (SPV) would be set up
to utilise the grants and implement the
developmental works on priority.
"As the largest contributor to the state
exchequer, Bengaluru has been witnessing
ambitious projects implemented under
the "Brand Bengaluru" to improve its
infrastructure, service delivery and vehicular
traffic," said Mr. Siddaramaiah while
presenting the State Budget for fiscal 2025-26
in the assembly on March 7, 2025.
the comprehensive development of Jain, Buddhist and
Sikh communities. Rs.250 crore will be provided for the
development of the Christian community. Honorarium
given to Jain priests, Chief Grantis of Sikhs and Pesh-
Imams of mosques will be enhanced to Rs.6,000 per month.
Honorarium given to Assistant Granti and Muezzin will be
increased to Rs.5,000 per month.
Financial assistance given in lieu of additional 5kg rice
under the Anna Bhagya Scheme launched with the
objective of mitigating the hunger of the poor across the
state will be replaced with 5kg additional rice. This will
provide additional rice to 4.21 crore beneficiaries.
The Vijayapura Airport being constructed at a cost of
Rs.348 crore will be operationalised in 2025-26. An amount
of Rs.53 crore has been released for the construction of
Raichur Airport, which is being undertaken at a total
project cost of Rs.219 crore.
The State Government has taken up nine projects with the
railways on a 50:50 basis. The land acquisition cost for seven
of these projects will be borne by the state. The state will
spend Rs.9,847 crore on these projects whose total project
cost is Rs.16,235 crore. An allocation of Rs.600 crore has
been made in 2025-26.
To provide a safe and good working environment for
women, it is proposed to construct 6,000-capacity working
women dormitories at Narasapura in Kolar district at a
cost of Rs. 173 crore and a working women's hostel in
Vasantanarasapura industrial area of Tumkur district at a
cost of Rs. 20 crore.

pages.content:
tourism across the state, the State Government has
announced a New Tourism Policy 2024-29, making
tourism a priority sector through holistic and sustainable
development. An investment of Rs.8,000 crore and job
creation of 1.5 lakh is aimed to be achieved through the
policy. Sri Renuka Yallamma Temple near Saundatti in
Belagavi district and Devika Rani Roerich Estate on the
outskirts of Bengaluru will be developed under the Special
Capital Assistance Scheme at a cost of Rs. 199 crore. Tourist
destinations in 10 select districts will be developed at a cost
of Rs. 50 crore in 2025-26.
Lower Revenue Deficit
Fiscal deficit for 2025-26 is estimated at 2.95 per cent of
GSDP. Both fiscal deficit and total liability have been
maintained within the limits prescribed in the Karnataka
Fiscal Responsibility Act. The total Budget size has
increased to Rs 4,09,549 crore in 2025-26 BE from Rs
3,71,383 crore in 2024-25 BE. The Budget size has increased
by Rs.38,166 crore with 10.3 per cent growth rate. Of the
total expenditure, revenue expenditure is Rs. 3,11,739
crore, an increase of 7.3 per cent compared to 2024-25 BE.
Capital expenditure (gross) has increased by 47.3 per cent
compared to 2024-25 BE.
In spite of revenue loss from the central government, the
state's revenue deficit is projected to reduce to Rs 19,262
crore in 2025-26 from Rs 27,354 crore in 2024-25. Fiscal
deficit is estimated at Rs.90,428 crore, which is 2.95 per
cent of GSDP and the total outstanding liabilities of the
state is estimated to reach Rs.7,64,655 crore at the end
of 2025-26, which is 24.91 per cent of GSDP. As per the
Karnataka Fiscal Responsibility Act, 2002, fiscal deficit
has to be within 3 per cent of GSDP and total outstanding
liabilities to be within 25 per cent of GSDP. This Budget has
fulfilled both the criteria mandated under the Karnataka
Fiscal Responsibility Act, 2002. Total borrowing has been
budgeted at Rs.1,16,000 crore for 2025-26.
"It is a matter of pride that we have managed to reduce the
revenue deficit in the ensuing year while covering all these
expenses. It indicates that our government is on track to
achieve a revenue surplus in the coming years. Though
more funds are provided for capital projects to support
economic growth, our government has adhered to fiscal
discipline," Mr. Siddaramaiah asserted.
The estimated total receipts, including loans in 2025-26 BE
stands at Rs.4,08,647 crore. Total receipts have increased by
Rs 39,973 crore, up 11 per cent over 2024-25. Total revenue
receipts for 2025-26 is estimated at Rs.2,92,477 crore, an
increase of Rs.29,299 crore or 11 per cent up compared
to the previous year. Revenue receipts include own tax
revenue, non-tax revenue, devolution and grant-in-aid
from the Government of India. State own tax revenue
receipts are estimated to be Rs.2,08,100 crore. Own tax
revenue has increased by Rs.18,207 crore over 2024-25 BE,
up 9.6 per cent. Rs.16,500 crore is estimated from non-tax
revenue, an increase of 22.2 per cent over the previous year.
Tax devolution from the Centre for 2025-26 is estimated to
be Rs.51,877 crore in 2024-25 BE.
Commercial Tax, State Excise, Stamps and Registration and
Motor Vehicle Tax are the major own tax revenues of the
state. As the second highest GST (Goods and Sales Tax)
revenue collecting state, Karnataka is projected to get Rs
1,05,000 crore in 2024-25. The department has set a target
of Rs 1,20,000 crore from GST in 2025-26. Professional
tax by salary and wage earners will be increased to Rs 300
from Rs 200 per month for February, 2025 to align with
the maximum limit permissible of Rs 2,500 per annum.
Similarly, revenue from excise is projected to be Rs 36,500
crore in revised estimates for 2024-25. The department has
set a target of Rs 40,000 crore for 2025-26.
To regulate property registration, the Stamps and
Registration department has made e-khata mandatory. Its
department has set a target of Rs 24,000 for 2024-25 and
Rs 28,000 crore for 2025-26. Likewise, Rs 12,500 crore
is estimated from Motor Vehicle Tax for 2024-25 and Rs
15,000 crore for 2025-26.

budgeted at Rs.1,16,000 crore for 2025-26.
"It is a matter of pride that we have managed to reduce the
revenue deficit in the ensuing year while covering all these
expenses. It indicates that our government is on track to
achieve a revenue surplus in the coming years. Though
more funds are provided for capital projects to support
economic growth, our government has adhered to fiscal
discipline," Mr. Siddaramaiah asserted.
The estimated total receipts, including loans in 2025-26 BE
stands at Rs.4,08,647 crore. Total receipts have increased by
Rs 39,973 crore, up 11 per cent over 2024-25. Total revenue
receipts for 2025-26 is estimated at Rs.2,92,477 crore, an
increase of Rs.29,299 crore or 11 per cent up compared
to the previous year. Revenue receipts include own tax
revenue, non-tax revenue, devolution and grant-in-aid
from the Government of India. State own tax revenue
receipts are estimated to be Rs.2,08,100 crore. Own tax
revenue has increased by Rs.18,207 crore over 2024-25 BE,
up 9.6 per cent. Rs.16,500 crore is estimated from non-tax
revenue, an increase of 22.2 per cent over the previous year.
Tax devolution from the Centre for 2025-26 is estimated to
be Rs.51,877 crore in 2024-25 BE.
Commercial Tax, State Excise, Stamps and Registration and
Motor Vehicle Tax are the major own tax revenues of the
state. As the second highest GST (Goods and Sales Tax)
revenue collecting state, Karnataka is projected to get Rs
1,05,000 crore in 2024-25. The department has set a target
of Rs 1,20,000 crore from GST in 2025-26. Professional
tax by salary and wage earners will be increased to Rs 300
from Rs 200 per month for February, 2025 to align with
the maximum limit permissible of Rs 2,500 per annum.
Similarly, revenue from excise is projected to be Rs 36,500
crore in revised estimates for 2024-25. The department has
set a target of Rs 40,000 crore for 2025-26.
To regulate property registration, the Stamps and
Registration department has made e-khata mandatory. Its
department has set a target of Rs 24,000 for 2024-25 and
Rs 28,000 crore for 2025-26. Likewise, Rs 12,500 crore
is estimated from Motor Vehicle Tax for 2024-25 and Rs

Governor Gehlot Hails Karnataka
as a Model of Inclusive Growth
· Shafi S
In a resounding address during the joint budget legislature session, Governor
Thaawarchand Gehlot underscored Karnataka's remarkable progress under
the Congress-led government, dismissing skepticism about the state's financial
stability amid expansive welfare initiatives. "Many predicted Karnataka would
lag in development and face fiscal collapse due to welfare schemes, but my
government has proven these doomsayers wrong," declared the Governor,
highlighting the state's robust economic trajectory and commitment to
equitable growth.
Governor Gehlot emphasized Karnataka's stellar economic performance,
noting the state's rising income and its position as a magnet for investments.
With record private capital inflows and ranking second in foreign direct
investment (FDI) nationally, Karnataka has solidified its status as an economic

pages.content:
powerhouse. The Governor also lauded the consistent
growth in GST collections, reflecting heightened economic
activity and efficient fiscal management.
A significant milestone is the near-complete implementation
of last year's budgetary promises: 331 out of 344 announced
initiatives have already been operationalized. This execution
efficiency, according to the Governor, underscores the
administration's dedication to translating promises into
tangible outcomes.
Welfare Schemes: Bridging Inequality,
Empowering Millions
Aligned with constitutional
mandates to reduce
inequality, Karnataka's guarantee schemes have emerged
as a cornerstone of its governance model. Over 1.25
crore families now benefit from direct cash transfers,
subsidies, and incentives across departments, mitigating
socio-economic disparities. "These schemes are not mere
expenditures but investments in human capital," asserted
Governor Gehlot, stressing their role in fostering inclusive
growth.
The Gruha Lakshmi, Shakti, and Anna Bhagya initiatives,
among others, have not only provided immediate relief but
also strengthened household resilience, enabling families to
participate more actively in the economy.
Beyond Bengaluru: Decentralizing
Development
A standout achievement highlighted was the success of the
Global Investors' Meet (GIM), which secured Memoranda
of Understanding (MoUs) worth Rs 10.27 lakh crore.
Notably, over 75% of these investments are earmarked
for regions outside Bengaluru, aligning with the 'Beyond
Bengaluru' vision to drive equitable regional development.
"This strategic dispersal ensures growth reaches every
corner of Karnataka," remarked the Governor, signaling a
transformative shift toward decentralized industrialization.
The state's ambitious goal to become a USD 1 trillion
economy hinges on such efforts, coupled with infrastructure
upgrades and skill development programs tailored to
emerging sectors.
Upholding Constitutional Values in
Governance
In a poignant segment, Governor Gehlot underscored the
government's resolve to safeguard constitutional principles
amid rising anti-constitutional sentiments. Over 1,500
Constitution awareness programs have been conducted
statewide, educating citizens about their rights and duties.
"If we protect the Constitution, it will protect us," he asserted,
linking democratic ethos to sustainable development.
The
administration's adherence to
constitutional
aspirations is further reflected in its welfare-centric
policies, such as implementing the Seventh Pay
Commission recommendations for government employees
and prioritizing marginalized communities in budgetary
allocations.
Innovative Governance for Holistic
Progress
Despite fiscal constraints, Karnataka has championed
innovative financing models to fund its welfare and
development agendas. The Governor highlighted multi-
sectoral programs aimed at social, economic, and cultural
advancement, including investments in education,
healthcare, and rural infrastructure. Initiatives like the
'Karnataka Digital Economy Mission' and renewable energy
projects exemplify the state's forward-looking approach.
Governor Gehlot concluded his address by reaffirming
Karnataka's commitment to a development model that
places citizens at its core. By harmonizing economic growth
with social justice, the state has crafted a blueprint for other
regions to emulate. "Our journey is guided by the belief that
progress must uplift every individual, not just a privileged
few," he stated.
As Karnataka advances toward its trillion-dollar vision, its
synthesis of constitutional integrity, welfare innovation,
and economic foresight offers a replicable framework for
India's federal landscape. The Governor's discourse stands
as both a chronicle of transformative governance and a
clarion call for collaborative nation-building-a testament
to leadership that prioritizes people over politics and
progress over partisanship.
March of Karnataka April 2025
12

he Kalyan Patha Scheme is ambitious rural road
development initiatives initiated by the Kalyana Karnataka
Region Development Board to improve connectivity
and promote economic growth in rural areas of Kalyana
Karnataka Region.
This project emphasis will be placed on building and
improving the road network, especially in underserved
areas. This is a revolutionary move for the transformation
of rural roads in Kalyana Karnataka.
Veteran leader leader of the opposition in Rajya Sabha and
who models article 371 (J) said, All these development
works are going on as a result of enactment of 371(J) Act.

Kalyan Karnataka region to construct 1,150 km road, and
Rs 5,190 crore will be spent under Pragati Patha scheme
across the state to construct 7110 km. He said that a
historic decision was taken and it's a road revolution can be
expected in the Rural Karnataka in the coming days.

Mallikarjun Kharge, for securing special status for the
region through Article 371(J) effecting establishment of to
Jayadeva Hospital, Kidwai Hospital, C.U.K. ESIC and many
other infrastructures have not only written a new language
for the development of the region but also led to the
economic independence of the people here. A person who
wins a war is not a hero, a person who wins people's love is a
real hero. Dr. Mallikarjuna Kharge said that Jananayak has
earned the love and trust of the people here.
He recalled that while national leaders fought for India's
independence, it was Kharge who ensured economic
empowerment for Kalyana Karnataka. The Deputy CM
emphasized that the state budget continues to allocate

given skills along with learning and strengthening the
infrastructure of health institutions at cost of Rs. 873 crore.
The board will allocate Rs. 358 crore for the development of
minorities and Rs 156 crore for the welfare of the backward.
He said that Praja Soudha are being constructed in the new
taluks announced in the region.
What is Kalyana Patha Yojana?
Kalyan Patha Scheme is specially designed for Kalyan
Karnataka region. It was earlier known as Hyderabad
Karnataka region. It includes Bidar, Bellary, Vijayanagar,
Kalaburagi, Koppal, Raichuru and Yadagiri districts.
The project focuses on developing 1,150 kilometers of rural
roads in 38 assembly constituencies. 1,000 crores in the
budget dedicated for this.
The scheme aims to improve road connectivity and support
rural development in historically underdeveloped areas.
This will promote economic activities and facilitate access
to essential services. This will facilitate connectivity, boost
local economies and improve the quality of life of people
in these areas. As rural road connectivity is an important
factor in increasing the economic and social development
of the region, there is a need to develop rural roads into all-
season roads. Development of rural roads into all-season
roads will provide connectivity to the district, taluk centers
and markets, hospitals, educational centers for the people
of the rural areas and will contribute to economic and
social development.
Along with Kalyana Patha for Kalyana Karnataka region,
the Pragati Path scheme announced in the Budget 2024-25
aims to systematically and qualitatively improve the rural
road network. The scheme involves the development of
about 7,110 kilometers of rural roads and the government
will invest an estimated ₹5,190 crore in this scheme. Under
this initiative, 50 kilometers of roads will be constructed for
each constituency in 189 rural assembly constituencies. The
funding structure includes external assistance of ₹3,633
crore and state contribution of ₹1,557 crore. The project
will repair about 1,500 kilometers of roads built nearly a
decade ago under earlier programs like Pradhan Mantri
Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) and Namma Gram Namma
Road Yojana (NGNRY).
What are key points of Pragati Patha
Objective: To systematically and qualitatively improve the
rural road network across Karnataka.
Scope: Development of about 7,110 kilometers of
rural roads, construction of 50 kilometers of roads per
constituency in 189 rural assembly constituencies.
Budget: Estimated Rs 5,190 crore, of which Rs 3,633 crore
1,557 crore from external assistance and Rs. Provided by
State grant.
The total length of existing rural roads in Kalyan Karnataka
region (as per 2019 DRRP) is 34,835.53 km.
District wise details of works proposed to be developed in
7 districts of Kalyan Karnataka under Kalyan Path Yojana
The project will be completed within the 2024-25 financial
year.
Out of these, approximately 7980 km of roads have already
been effectively developed under the Centrally Sponsored

announced that a total of 1150 km of roads will be
developed at a cost of Rs.1000 crores in the 38 rural
assembly constituencies of Kalyan Karnataka on the model

OBJECTIVE: To enhance road connectivity and support

includes Bidar, Bellary, Vijayanagar, Kalaburagi, Koppal,
Raichuru and Yadagiri districts.

Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar and AICC President and 2. Preparation of DPRs
leader of the opposition in Rajya Sabha Mallikarjun Kharge
officially inaugurated it.
1,000 crore under the "Kalyana Patha" scheme announced
for 38 assembly constituencies in Kalyan Karnataka. Chief
Minister Siddaramaiah has announced in the budget for
2025-26 that a total of 286 road works will be completed
soon.
The Government of Karnataka follows a systematic process
for sanctioning roads under the Kalyan Path schemes. The
steps in that process are as follows:
1.
Identification of Roads for Development : Gram
Panchayat and Local Authorities: Identify roads
based on local needs, submitted to respective Taluk
Panchayat or Zilla Panchayat.
MLA Recommendations: Each MLA (Member of
Legislative Assembly) can suggest priority roads in
his constituency.
Public Works Department (PWD) and Department
of Rural Development and Panchayat Raj (RDPR)
prepare the final list of roads by conducting surveys
based on road connectivity, economic impact and
feasibility.
A Detailed Project Report (DPR) is prepared for each
selected road.
A grant of ₹28 crore has been earmarked for
preparation of DPR.
The report shall include the following:
Road length and location
Estimated construction cost
Current Status and Needed Improvements
Environmental and social impact
3.
Sanction and Approval :
District Level Approval: District Collectors and Zilla
Panchayat Chief Executive Officer (CEO) review the
proposals.
Finalized plans are sent to the state government.
KKRDB Approval: Public Works Department
(PWD) and Rural Development and Panchayat Raj
Department (RDPR) evaluate the detailed project
reports.
March of Karnataka April 2025
16

lines.text: Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar and AICC President and 2. Preparation of DPRs
leader of the opposition in Rajya Sabha Mallikarjun Kharge
officially inaugurated it.
1,000 crore under the "Kalyana Patha" scheme announced
for 38 assembly constituencies in Kalyan Karnataka. Chief
Minister Siddaramaiah has announced in the budget for
2025-26 that a total of 286 road works will be completed
soon.
The Government of Karnataka follows a systematic process
for sanctioning roads under the Kalyan Path schemes. The
steps in that process are as follows:
Identification of Roads for Development : Gram
Panchayat and Local Authorities: Identify roads
based on local needs, submitted to respective Taluk
Panchayat or Zilla Panchayat.
MLA Recommendations: Each MLA (Member of
Legislative Assembly) can suggest priority roads in
his constituency.
Public Works Department (PWD) and Department
of Rural Development and Panchayat Raj (RDPR)
prepare the final list of roads by conducting surveys
based on road connectivity, economic impact and
feasibility.
A Detailed Project Report (DPR) is prepared for each
selected road.
A grant of ₹28 crore has been earmarked for
preparation of DPR.
The report shall include the following:
Road length and location
Estimated construction cost
Current Status and Needed Improvements
Environmental and social impact
Sanction and Approval :
District Level Approval: District Collectors and Zilla
Panchayat Chief Executive Officer (CEO) review the
proposals.
Finalized plans are sent to the state government.
KKRDB Approval: Public Works Department
(PWD) and Rural Development and Panchayat Raj
Department (RDPR) evaluate the detailed project
reports.
March of Karnataka April 2025

pages.content:
Karnataka Legislature Book Fair
debuts with grand success
. Michael Patrao
S
For the first time, the precincts of Vidhana Soudha, the
seat of Karnataka Secretariat, hosted a four-day Karnataka
Legislature Book Fair-2025 and cultural festival from
February 27 to March 3.
Thousands of book lovers streamed into the Vidhana Soudha
on all the four days of the exhibition. The fair provided free
public entry through the four gates of Vidhana Soudha,
ensuring easy accessibility to all.
Spearheaded by assembly speaker U.T. Khader, hosted
over 150 bookstores mostly selling Kannada books with
discounts besides hosting a series of panels and poetry
sessions.
A special committee comprising officials from various
departments, including the Kannada and Culture
Department, was formed to ensure the event's systematic
execution. The Committee had decided that 80 percent
of the books would be in Kannada and the rest in other
languages.
Chief Minister Siddaramaiah inaugurated the event on
February 27, accompanied by distinguished literary figures,
including Jnanpith awardee Dr. Chandrashekhar Kambar,
Konkani writer Damodar Mauju, Deputy Speaker Basavaraj
Horatti, and Deputy Chief Minister D.K. Shivakumar.
Speaking at the inauguration, Siddaramaiah emphasized
the importance of reading, stating, "Books enrich our
knowledge and make us more humane. Everyone should
cultivate the habit of reading and build personal libraries
at home."
Quoting a Kannada proverb that emphasises wide travel
and deep study to attain knowledge (Desha Suttu Kosha
Odu), Siddaramaiah said: Reading books furthers our
knowledge. However, it's not enough if we read and become
educated.Literature should humanise us."
The chief minister urged people to encourage reading
among children. "Today's children are addicted to TV,
mobile and social media. Instead, let them get addicted to
books."
He urged people not to borrow others' books but rather buy
them themselves, Siddaramaiah said he would buy books to
his liking from the fair in the next few days.
Speaking on the occasion, the Legislative Assembly speaker
U T Khader said, "The idea of this event is to remove the
barrier between Vidhana Soudha and the public. The people
and writers, scholars and thinkers should not be away from
the Vidhana Soudha. They need to be brought closer for a
good collaboration, to ensure the state's welfare. Opening
up the gates of the Vidhana Soudha is a symbolic first step"
Mr. Khader assured that he would continue to hold the
book fair annually till he continues as the speaker of the
assembly, and hoped his successors also continue the good
practice. "There are also suggestions that a similar book
fair should be held in Suvarna Soudha ahead of the winter
session. We will look into that as well, depending on the
response to this fair in Bengaluru," he said.
Mr Khader mentioned that legislators are encouraged
to utilize Rs. 2 to 3 lakh from their MLA Local Area
Development funds to purchase books for government
schools, colleges, and public libraries in their constituencies.
March of Karnataka April 2025
18

pages.content:
This initiative aimed to enhance educational resources and
promote a culture of reading among students.
Speaking on the occasion Deputy Chief Minister D K
Shivakumar said "Technology has advanced a lot and
ChatGPT immediately gives a lot of answers. However,
there's a saying that if we forget our roots, we cannot get
the fruits. Books are our roots and historical anecdotes can
only be learnt through them," Shivakumar said.
While appreciating the initiative, Kannada writer Boluvaru
Mohammed Kunhi advised the government to promote
reading culture.
The four-day book fair also became a platform for a host
of panel discussions on literature, four poetry meets,
publishing industry in Kannada which saw leading writers
of Kannada participate. including Jnanpith award winning
Kannada writer Chandrashekhara Kambar participated.
Several new books will be released at the book fair.
Daily poetry readings, book launches, and panel discussions
were organised engaging both authors and readers. Each
evening featured cultural performances, celebrating
Karnataka's rich heritage through music, dance, and theatre,
providing attendees with a holistic cultural experience.
A highlight of the festival was the musical evening led by
renowned composer and actor Sadhu Kokila on March 2.
Noted publishers such as Sahitya Bhandra, Ankita
Pustaka, Navakarnataka, Gauri Lankesh Patrike, Bhavana
Prakashana, Abhinava and Akriti were among the
Bengaluru publishers who have displayed their books.
Universities and media houses also participated in the fair.
English translations of several popular novels were also
available.
Udayanhanu Kala Sangha displayed its flagship publication,
"Bangalore Darshana", a three-volume, 3000 plus pages
tracing the history, culture and other aspects of Bengaluru
City.
Various academies had put up stalls displaying their
respective publications including Kannads Sahitya
Parishat, Karnataka Lalit Kala Academy, Karnataka
Tulu Sahitya Parishat, Karnataka Yakshagana Academy,
Kuvempu Bhashabharati Authority, Kannada Development
Authority, Kannada Book Authority, Kannada and Culture
Department.
Karnataka Beary Sahitya Academy displayed its publications
including "Beary Bhashe" and "The Beary's of Tulunad", a
history of the Beary community.
There were many enthusiasts of scholarly works by
Benjamin Lewis Rice including "Epigraphia Carnatica"
in the stall of Prasaranga, the publication wing of Mysore
University. The publication wing of Kannada University,
Hampi also displayed its publications.
The festival also provided a platform for authors to launch
their books and engage with readers. Notable literary figures,
including Jnanpith awardee Chandrashekhar Kambara,
Damodar Mauzo of Goa, and Boluvaru Muhammad Kunhi,
were honored during the event.
Khader said, "We got a very good response, with 80,000
people visiting the fair on Sunday and 55,000 during the
two previous days."
He hinted at the possibility of organizing a similar fair at
Suvarna Vidhana Soudha before the winter session. "As
long as I am the Speaker, this tradition will continue," he
assured.
Governor Thaawar Chand Gehlot also visited the fair and
interacted with children.
The success of this inaugural event has set a precedent for
future editions. This initiative marks a significant cultural
milestone, blending legislative spaces with literary and
cultural activities, and is poised to become a recurring
celebration in Karnataka's cultural calendar.
March of Karnataka April 2025
19

pages.content:
Celebrating
World Heritage Day
April 18
Karnataka Heritage
'Guthu Mane Glory'
· I J Saldanha-Shet
...
The side view of the entrance of Guthu Mane in Mangalore.
The Premier Southern State of Karnataka and its folk at
all levels take great pride and march ahead of the pack
where Heritage, History and Legend are concerned. The
scholarship, research and records have played a yeoman
role and common people have always upheld and treasured
the renowned folklore and lofty traditions like few can
claim and be proud of. Today, the Karnataka Govt and
administration is playing a leading and encouraging role in
furthering the quality and quantity quotients to give a head
start in the International arena to the tourist, economic and
technological progress for Karnataka to March ahead and
declare every progress for the people, of the people and by
the people. It is a matter of pride and blessing for Kannada
culture and wherever Kannadigas are found the world
over. Karnataka ethos includes the rich Tuluva heritage
of Karavali Karnataka (Coastal Karnataka) to edify and
sustain the Global reach in this regard, with mega support
of the leaders and administrators of Karnataka.
Legendary Guthu Mane Systems:
This stunning history is deep indeed "The Tuluva
Vijayanagara Empire' is a paramount part of South Indian
history going back centuries. Kudla, Mangaluru/Mangalore
must be aware and proud that Vijayanagar dynasty was
rooted here. Our folks and many scholars are aware that the
several palatial structures here are the unassuming humble
monuments of the 'Guthu' systems of 'representative rule'
mainly by Krishnadevaraya. The Kudala main throne house
of authority is given to the 'Patta' Shetty clan to collect the
dues and taxes of the common people and ensure they get
their rights, fruits and peace in full measure. 'Kodialguthu'
is in the vicinity of 'Kudla Sangama' the meeting of rivers
and thus the main regent. A visit and beholding the basic
glory of this Mane (house) that has maintained the glory
of the old feudal system is pleasure.
Kodialguthu Mane, a traditional Tuluva residence in
Mangalore city is one that elicits deep admiration and
interest;
currently owned by sisters Jyoti Alva and
Dr. Pratibha Karanth. Jyoti Alva resides in the main house,
which has been preserved to maintain its traditional
architecture, pictures here throw light on the Guthu Mane.
Dr. Pratibha Karanth, primarily based in Bangalore, has
restored a portion of the property, known as the 'hebbagilu',
transforming it into the Kodialguthu Center for Art &
Culture. This center serves as a venue for art exhibitions
and cultural events, collaborating with organizations
like the INTACH Mangaluru Chapter to promote the
region's heritage, in Mangalore, Dakshina Kannada,
with the traditional Guthu Mane architecture of the Bunt
community.
The architectural layout of a Guthu Mane includes several
distinctive features: Tudame: A bamboo gate that slides
into wooden posts, marking the entrance. Jaal: An open

pages.content:
The World Heritage Day, celebrated globally on April
18th. This day is dedicated to raising awareness about
the importance of preserving and promoting cultural
heritage, making it the perfect occasion to highlight
the rich legacy of Karnataka's Guthu Mane system. The
article on Mangalore's heritage houses, particularly the
Kodialguthu Mane, aligns seamlessly with the spirit of
World Heritage Day by showcasing the architectural
brilliance, historical depth, and cultural traditions
of the Tuluva community. By featuring this piece,
the magazine not only honors Karnataka's unique
heritage but also underscores the state's commitment
to preserving its historical landmarks for future
generations.
space shaded with dried coconut leaves, providing relief
from the sun. Kall Chapadi: A stone bench for visitors to
rest. Kalla Marai: A rock-cut container used for washing
feet before entering the main house. Mogasale: A sit-out
area leading to the main door. Hebbagilu: The grand main
door opening into the Angala, a covered courtyard with
intricately carved walls. Over time, many Guthu Manes
faced challenges due to land reforms and urbanization.
"Guthu Mane" (7) 3) refers to the traditional ancestral
houses of dominant families in Tulu Nadu. These were
landholding families (Guthu families) who controlled vast
lands, local administration, and social order. The Guthu
houses followed matrilineal (Aliyasantana) inheritance,
meaning property passed through the mother's lineage. The
head of the family was called "Guthu Patra", and assumed
the name 'Devu Shetty' and central to village governance.
Vijayanagara Empire : During the Vijayanagara period
(1336-1646 CE), the empire had a significant influence
on the West Coast, including Tulu Nadu. The Guthu Mane
system thrived under Vijayanagara rule due to: Military
& Administrative ties Vijayanagara Empire relied on local
chieftains (Nayakas) and wealthy families (Guthu families)
for administration and military support. Some Guthu
families acted as local governors or provided soldiers for the
Vijayanagara army. Patronized Kannada, Telugu, Sanskrit,
and Tamil literature. Promoted Hinduism but was tolerant
of other religions. Flourishing fine arts, dance, and music
(Carnatic music evolved). Its influence remains in South
Indian culture, temple architecture, and literature. Hampi
is now a famous historical and tourist site. The Guthu Mane
traditions are worthy to experience in Mangaluru city and
nearby. The Vijayanagara Empire was one of the most
powerful and prosperous empires in South Indian history.
-
The new addition to the Guthu Mane.
A swing and a palanquin, symbols of the rich, at the courtyard
of Guthu Mane.
Paintings of some of the landmark buildings in coastal region,
adorning the walls of Guthu Mane.
Ms Jyothi Alva, the current owner in the courtyard of Guthu Mane.

pages.content:
Dharwad & Dr. B.R. Ambedkar:
A Forgotten Legacy of Reform and Resilience
.DINESH NAYAK
The moment one refers the name of
Dharwad, it's rich legacy in th areas
of music and literature flashes in
mind, not speak about the delicious
Peda, for which this north Karnatak
city is equally famous for. However,
not many are aware that this city
nestled in shadow of the Western
Ghats has an enduring connection
with B.R. Ambedkar, the principal
architect of the Constitution and a
champion of Dalit rights.
Among the buildings that stand
testimony to his activities in the
State include a tiled-roof structure
where Dr. Ambedkar stayed with
wife, Ramabai, for a few months.
Then there is a hostel he built for
Dalit students and another which
once housed the co-operative
society of Dalits established at his
behest. But little about them is
docum ented.
Dr. Ambedkar's tryst with
Dharwad began in the 1920s. He
turned curious about this city
when he discovered that it was an
"untouchable" from the region,
who was instrumental in securing
admission for Dalit children in
schools way back in 1856.
When a school in Dharwad denied
admission to the son of this
person (referred to simply as "the
Mahar from Dharwad" in Bombay
government records) because of his
caste, he approached the Bombay

lines.text: Dharwad & Dr. B.R. Ambedkar:
A Forgotten Legacy of Reform and Resilience
.DINESH NAYAK
The moment one refers the name of
Dharwad, it's rich legacy in th areas
of music and literature flashes in
mind, not speak about the delicious
Peda, for which this north Karnatak
city is equally famous for. However,
not many are aware that this city
nestled in shadow of the Western
Ghats has an enduring connection
with B.R. Ambedkar, the principal
architect of the Constitution and a
champion of Dalit rights.
Among the buildings that stand
testimony to his activities in the
State include a tiled-roof structure
where Dr. Ambedkar stayed with
wife, Ramabai, for a few months.
Then there is a hostel he built for
Dalit students and another which
once housed the co-operative
society of Dalits established at his
behest. But little about them is
docum ented.
Dr. Ambedkar's tryst with
Dharwad began in the 1920s. He
turned curious about this city
when he discovered that it was an
"untouchable" from the region,
who was instrumental in securing
admission for Dalit children in
schools way back in 1856.
When a school in Dharwad denied
admission to the son of this
person (referred to simply as "the
Mahar from Dharwad" in Bombay
government records) because of his
caste, he approached the Bombay
Native Education Society head,
Edward Elphinston, who in turn
forwarded his plea to East India
Company. The British government
subsequently issued orders allowing
admission in its schools to all
affording to pay the fee irrespective
of social standings. A curious Dr.
Ambedkar later came to Dharwad
searching for that person's family
in 1927. Though he could not trace
them, it cemented his connection
with the city. The person Dr.

pages.content:
Ambedkar looked for remains
unknown to this day.
His next visit began on a personal
note, when Ramabai took ill and
needed a change of weather to
recuperate. In 1929, Dr.
Ambedkar and his wife
not only lived here for a
few months, but also made
Dharwad the launching pad
to expand his activities of
Dalit amelioration in the
south.
The co-op experiment
One of the ventures started by
Dr. Ambedkar during his stay
in Dharwad was the setting
up of a cooperative society of
Dalits.
Activist Lakshman Bakkai said
the Machigar Cooperative Credit
Society was set up by two of his
followers - Parashuram N. Pawar
and Yallappa Hongal - cobblers
by profession. They are believed
to have taken part in the historic
Mahad Satyagraha, headed by Dr.
Ambedkar.
Interestingly, the first members were
all humble cobblers. But
Dr. Ambedkar infused in them
courage and guided them. It was a
big success and when the society
moved to its own building,
Dr. Ambedkar came down to
Dharwad to inaugurate it. Today,
the society is not active, but the
To mark Ambedkar Jayanti on 14th April,
March of Karnataka's April issue highlights
Dr. B.R. Ambedkar's lesser-known connection
to Dharwad. The article explores his visits to
the town, his efforts to uplift marginalized
groups, and how his ideas inspired social
reforms in Karnataka. The article reminds us
why Ambedkar's vision of fairness and dignity
remains vital today, urging readers to reflect
on its importance in building a more inclusive
society. A fitting tribute to his life and ideals, it
echoes April's theme of renewal and hope.
old building exists. "It should be
preserved and developed into a
museum," Mr. Bakkai said.
A student hostel
During his stay in the region,
Dr. Ambedkar encouraged Dalit
youth in Dharwad and surrounding
areas to pursue education. To
help such students, he built the
Depressed Classes Student's Hostel
at Koppadakeri here in 1929.
Dr. Ambedkar approached the
district collector and obtained
two acres of land for the purpose.
The college managing trustee, F.
I. Jakkappanavar has said that the
original title deed of this land was in
Dr. Ambedkar's name.
Dr. Ambedkar himself served
as the managing trustee of the
society and ran the hostel for
many years. Wife Ramabai too had
great concern for the hostel. His
trusted follower,
B.H. Varale, was appointed the
honorary superintendent of the
hostel.
It is said that When Dr. Ambedkar
could not send money to India
when he was in England to attend
the Round Table Conference in
1931, he asked Ramabai to visit
Dharwad, and she found the school
in bad shape. She immediately sold
her gold ornaments and arranged
for money and ration. In later
years, local residents took charge
of the hostel. Former Minister
Basavalingappa built a residential
school here in 1967.
Dr Ambedkar's connection with
Dharwad is an important as well
interesting chapter of our modern
history. Fortunately, the buildings
connected to Dr Ambedkar are the
standing testimonials for his tryst
with Karnataka.

029
BIFFes confers lifetime achievement
award on Shabana Azmi
Mikka Bannada Hakki gets best Kannada Film Award
· S Viswanath
The 16th Edition of Bengaluru International Film Festival
- BIFFes - called curtains after seven days of celebrations
culminating by bestowing the Lifetime Achievement
Award on renowned actress Shabana Azmi and picking
Mikka Bannada Hakki as the Best Kannada Film.
While Shabana's friend and noted theatre personality
Arundathi Nag received the award on Shabana's behalf
earlier at the closing ceremony, the award was later conferred
on Shabana Azmi by Chief Minister Siddaramaiah at his
Home Office - Cauvery - when the actress called on him
along with eminent lyricist, script writer and husband Javed
Akthar.
Conferring the award Chief Minister Siddaramaih fondly
reminiscened and recollected Shabana Azmi's role in the
iconic video song 'Mile Sur Mera Tumhara'. The Chief
Minister appreciated her indelible impact on Indian cinema
and culture.
Chief Minister
Siddaramaiah
further highlighted
Karnataka's contribution to Hindustani classical music,
noting that legendary musicians like Bhimsen Joshi, Kumar
Gandharva, and Gangubai Hangal hailed from Dharwad, a
region renowned for its classical music heritage.
Shabana Azmi, who has essayed a multitude of roles in her
chequered career, especially in off-beat films, made her
debut in Sandalwood in the 1970s in the film Kanneswara
Rama directed by renowned director M S Sathyu, won the
hearts of Kannada cinema lovers, the chief minister vividly
recalled.
Heaping praises on her, Chief Minister pointed out that
Shabana Azmi established herself as a distinguished
artist in South Indian films as well as Hindi cinema. This
honour, awarded in recognition of her nearly 50 years of
contribution to the art of cinema, adds to the prestige of the
award itself, he said.
March of Karnataka April 2025
24

pages.content:
FIAPF
Ben
ru
tional
alor'
Principal Secretary B B Cauvbery, Department of
Information & Public Relations Commissioner Hemant
Nimbalkar, Additional Chief Secretary L.K. Atheeq,
Karnataka Chalanachitra Academy President Sadhu
Kokila, welcomed Shabana Azmi and Javed Akhtar on the
occasion.
Shabana Azmi, who recently completed 50 years in the
film industry, and has been the face of the "other" or "off-
beat" cinemas of India, was picked for the award which
befittingly fell on International Women's Day. The Award,
besides the citation, carries a cash prize of Rs 10 lakh. The
citation extolled the sterling actress appreciating her "for
illuminating the screen with performances of rare depth and
authenticity, for fearlessly embracing roles that challenge
conventions, for the portrayals of complex, defiant women
and for being an unwavering voice in gender discourse. This
award is given in honor of the unparalleled contributions to
cinema and the tireless advocacy for equality, justice, and
human dignity"
Incidentally, it has been decided that the Lifetime
Achievement Award would be alternatively bestowed
upon an international personality and Indian personality
of eminence for their contributions to the growth and
development of cinema. The previous recepients of the
award include film director M S Sathyu, Mani Ratnam.
Meanwhile, at the closing ceremony, Labour Minister
Santosh, who gave away the awards, championing the cause
of providing and protecting the single screen theatres across
the State, stressed the need for more content-oriented,
aesthetic and thematic films which could be screened in
these theatres.
The 16th Edition of BIFFes saw another successful and
fascinating chapter having screened 150 plus films in various
sections, besides academic sessions and workshops, with
enthusiastic cinephiles catching the best of contemporary
cinemas at the annual flagship cinema jamboree.
BIFFes, which saw three different competition sections
namely the Kannada Cinema Competition, the Indian
Cinema Competition and the Asian Cinema Competition,
saw the Kannada film Mikka Bannada Hakki directed by
the young and promising director Manohara K bag the Best
Kannada Film Award. Besides the citation, the award also
carries a cash prize of Rs 10 lakh for the winner. The citation
extolling the film for its "poetic storytelling and subtle
narrative make it a deeply moving cinematic experience,
celebrating the strength of the human spirit."
In a remarkable achievement for the Tulu language films, you
had Pidayi by Santhosh Mada "for tackling untouchability
linked to menstruation, the film's rich visuals and powerful
message inspire awareness and social change" bagging the
Second Best Film and Aneesh Poojary's Daskath being

pages.content:
adjudged the Third best films in the Kannada Cinema
Competiton "for highlighting the struggles of ordinary
people forced to surrender their dignity before an egoistic,
powerful officer - until they rise, fight back, and reclaim
their self-respect." The prizes carrying cash award of Rs 5
lakh and Rs 2 lakh respectively. Krishnegowda's Kannada
film Lacchi lifted the NETPAC (Network for the Promotion
of Asian Cinema) Award for being "a modern film that
portrays global issues such as child abduction, violence
against women, and corruption within law enforcement
shown with excellent performances and contemporary
filmmaking."
Likewise, the honours of the coveted Best Indian Film
Award went to the Hindi film Humans In The Loop, directed
by Aranya Sahay, which seamlessly melds the themes of AI
(Artificial Intelligence and humanity). Humans In The Loop
also bagged the international critics - FIPRESCI Award
which noted that "the film manages to question both the
traditions and the new technologies, putting in perspective,
through the use of AI, identity issues in a new technological
age that pretends to be neutral. It's a very local story, and
a very global one at the same time, a testament to the fact
that a highly personal and grounded vision will always be,
in some way, universal."
Malayalam thriller Level Cross by Arfaz Ayub which
"provides the experience of genre storytelling of troubled
lives through captivating world building," clinching the
second place, while Swaha third position in the Indian
Cinema Competition, which "depicts the struggle of
untouchables in society, in desolate social situation while
redeeming hope through individual action." The citation
stating Humans In The Loop "explores the challenges of
indigenous society and the looming repercussions of AI."
The Kannada film Bellihoo by Sebastin David competing
in the section won the Special Jury Mention Award as the
"film explores the life of a subaltern woman, in a trying
profession, struggling to make the world a better place
through compassion."
In the Asian Cinema Competition, the Iranian film In The
Land of Brothers by the directors-duo Raha Amirfazli
and Alireza Ghasemi, while Reading Lolita In Tehran the
Israeli film by Eran Riklis and director Maksud Hossain's
Bangladesh film Saba bagging the first, second and third
prizes respectively.
The citation stating that "In The Land Of Brothers tackles
universal topic of displacement and forced migration
from the war inflicted countries. Through cleverly crafted
narrative structure, the movie depicts transgenerational
trauma of war refugees. The world of story is structured
as a multilayered, spatial and temporal narrative, using
evocative cinematic language, and transcending borders
and time, offering a deeply human and empathetic
perspective on survival, memory, and resilience."
The citation appreciating "Reading Lolita In Tehran for
its courageous and moving portrayal of resilience and
intellectual freedom in the face of oppression. By weaving
the autobiographical journey of a fearless teacher who defies
State's restrictions, the film becomes a powerful testament
to the power of literature and the spirit of education."
The citation observing that Saba "through the lens of a non-
conventional mother-daughter relationship story, fraught
with tension and love, the film captures the profound
complexities of generational divides, cultural expectations,
and personal values. With powerful storytelling, it delves
into the heart of human relationships, offering an honest
and thought-provoking portrayal of conflicting perspectives
on autonomy and dignity, highlighting female agency and
women empowerment."
Incidentally, in the Asian Cinema Competition, Fasil
Muhammed's Malayalam movie Feminichi Fathima won
the Special Jury Mention along with Vinod Kapri's Pyre
which flagged off the week-long BIFFes film festival. If
Feminichi Fathima won the juror's appreciation for "its
blend of humour and social commentary, creating a
poignant yet entertaining exploration of gender equality,
cultural traditions, and personal empowerment, through
the journey of its determinate protagonist, Fathima."
Kapri's Pyre was "appreciated for its compelling portrayal of
the universal themes of loneliness, abandonment, and the
enduring resilience of the human spirit, through the story
an ageing couple. The film captures the intricate balance
between despair and hope, as well as the deep emotional
connection with the land."
The Kannada film charts the Sisphyean struggles of a young
girl afflicted with vitiligo who is scorned by society and her
own father but braves her way in life thanks to a kind mother
and a physical training teacher at school. Based on real life
story and adapted from Sonia S's autobiography it looks at a
young girl's coming-of-age against tremendous odds. How
the girl rises from bleak reality of poverty through sheer
strength of will forms the fulcrum of the touching tale.
Sahay's Humans In The Loop narrates the story of an
Adivasi woman Nehma, following her divorce from her
upper caste husband Ritesh, in order to gain custody of
her two children, joins as a data-labeller in an Artificial
Intelligence (AI) centre in the village. Nehma soon realises
that AI comes with several biases which discriminate
against her own community and that it must be treated like
her own children, who must be taught things.
March of Karnataka April 2025

lyricist Javed Akhtar, Karnataka Chalanachitra Academy Chairman Saadhu Kokila, and Commissioner for Information and Public
Relations Hemant Nimbalkar were present, celebrating her remarkable contributions to Indian cinema.

Chief Minister Siddaramaiah launched 135 mobile health check up ambulance units for construction labourers, at a
programme organised by the Labour Department in Bengaluru. Labour Minister Santhosh Lad and MLA Rizwan Arshad were
present on the occasion. The vehicles will go to various construction sites for the benefit of construction labourers.
